Dear Mr. ___,

I am writing to provide a comprehensive summary of your recent stay at [Hospital Name] from February 10 to February 14, 2024. During your admission, you were diagnosed with lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism (J18.1), accompanied by the DRG classification of simple pneumonia and pleurisy with major complications or comorbidities (MCC).

You initially presented on February 10, 2024, with symptoms of cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon evaluation, your vital signs showed a temperature of 38.5°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92%. A chest X-ray revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe, consistent with pneumonia.

Empirical antibiotic therapy with Amoxicillin IV was initiated promptly, with a dose of 500 mg administered every 8 hours, supplemented by Paracetamol as needed. Initial laboratory tests showed elevated CRP levels at 60 mg/L and a WBC count of 12 x10^9/L, signifying an inflammatory response.

In the days following admission, your condition showed a positive response to the treatment regimen. By February 11, your CRP levels began to decline to 50 mg/L, and your WBC decreased to 11 x10^9/L. It was noted that clinical improvements corresponded with a reduction in your temperature to 37.8°C and better oxygen saturation at 94%.

By February 12, significant progress was recorded with your temperature normalizing to 37°C and oxygen saturation stabilizing at 96%. The decision was made to transition you to oral antibiotics the following day, maintaining Amoxicillin at 250 mg daily, while continuing Atorvastatin PO 20 mg nightly.

On February 13, the clinical team observed continued improvement, with CRP levels further reduced to 20 mg/L and WBC count to 7 x10^9/L. Your vital signs indicated stability across various parameters, prompting the planning for your discharge.

At the time of discharge on February 14, your condition is much improved and medically stable. You are released with instructions to complete a 5-day course of oral antibiotics. It is recommended that you attend a follow-up appointment at the outpatient clinic in two weeks to assess your recovery progress and ensure no complications arise.

Should you have any questions or experience any symptoms such as increased shortness of breath, high fever, or other concerning changes, please do not hesitate to contact our office immediately. It has been our pleasure caring for you, and we wish you a healthy recovery.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. ___  
Resident Physician
